linkTarget.anchoringText: Generally, poorly sorted and angular depositions have higher friction angle than well sorted and round grains, which as a result of compaction, increases with time. Over time as overburden pressure increases, in presence of horizontal stress due to low Poisson’s ratio, the sediments can withstand larger shear stress as shown by Fig. 1 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Mohr Diagram of a Sedimentary rock under Compaction

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mohr Diagram of a Sedimentary rock under Compaction

linkTarget.anchoringText: By way of example, Figure 1 conceptually illustrates a detection method for reading tiltmeter data in reservoir management. As shown in this figure, a set of tiltmeter arrays 22 and GPS data sources 24 are present. In principle, tiltmeters are much like an extremely sensitive carpenters bubble level. When a sensor in a tiltmeter tilts, resistance between electrodes changes. The raw field data of each tiltmeter is read and captured, then provided for analysis and reporting, as described next by reference to Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Young’s Modulus and Poisson’s ratio for different types of rocks (Courtesy-J.H Schon)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Young’s Modulus and Poisson’s ratio for different types of rocks (Courtesy-J.H Schon)

linkTarget.anchoringText: A microstructure of California’s diatomite is shown in Fig. 3. The dark space in the SEM image representspore space. Its highly porous nature and weak inter layer connections, makes diatomites fragile and brittle. Moreover, fracture toughness of diatomites is very low because of negligible grain interlocking or cementation (Barenblatt et al 2002). But, diatomite’s brittleness and low fracture strength is the key to flow of oil and gas in a rock type that is practically impermeable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Microstructure of Bel ridge diatomites (Barenblatt et al 2002)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microstructure of Bel ridge diatomites (Barenblatt et al 2002)

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Structure of Backward Propagation Neural Network

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structure of Backward Propagation Neural Network

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, in reality, compaction in the edge is smaller due to arching effect. The constraint effect of sideburden, and surface deformation will form a subsidence bowl caused by the arching effect of the overburden, as shown in Fig. 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Subsidence and compaction for idealized versus real behavior

formatted-caption.caption-text: Subsidence and compaction for idealized versus real behavior

linkTarget.anchoringText: A recent numerical study by Fakcharoenphol et al. (2012) shows waterflood-induced stress change in the rock. The synergestic effect of reservoir cooling and pore pressure increase during waterflooding can significantly trigger rock failure, potentially reactivating healed natural fractures and creating new microfractures (Fig. 8)2 This process may also result rock movement such as compaction, and/or fault activation, which continuously modify reservoir properties such as the porosities, the permabilities and the fault transmissibilities.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Mohr diagram for stress change during water injection (Fakcharoenphol er ai., 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mohr diagram for stress change during water injection (Fakcharoenphol er ai., 2012)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 1 conceptually illustrates a detection method for reading tiltmeter data in reservoir management in some embodiments.
Figure 2 conceptually illustrates an analysis and reporting method for analyzing the tiltmeter readings and reporting on reservoir management in some embodiments.
Figure 3 conceptually illustrates a reservoir management method for determining whether to terminate injection production in some embodiments.
Figure 4 conceptually illustrates a schematic of reservoir management through surface microdeformation monitoring in some embodiments.
